general_requirements.statewide_program_name: No statewide framework. Requirements vary by AHJ. Most cities require building and electrical permits. PE stamps typically required for systems over 10 kW. New consumer protection laws SB 1036/SB 1697 effective September 2025.

interconnection.net_metering_details: No statewide net metering. Some retail electric providers offer buyback programs. CenterPoint Energy handles interconnection for Houston area. Oncor for DFW area.
interconnection.fees: CenterPoint: application fee varies; Oncor: varies by system size

special_considerations.hoa_restrictions: Texas Property Code 202.010 protects solar. HOAs cannot prohibit solar but can set aesthetic guidelines.
special_considerations.historic_districts: Local historic district rules apply. El Paso historic districts require plan review.
special_considerations.wind_load_requirements: Coastal areas have hurricane wind requirements. Design wind speeds vary 90-150 mph.
special_considerations.snow_load_requirements: Generally minimal. Panhandle/West Texas may have 10-15 psf.

licensing.license_type: Master Electrician license required. San Antonio requires city-registered master electrician. TDLR registration for solar retailers effective September 2025.

notes: Largest deregulated electricity market. Houston implemented SolarAPP+ July 2024. Dallas requires two separate online portals. Austin has streamlined green energy permits. San Antonio requires CPS Energy approval. PE stamp >10 kW in most metros. New consumer protection laws (SB 1036/SB 1697) require retailer registration.
